text: So we saw how our to form of the verb, to come, to eat, to tolerate, how would to tolerate be?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So our to form ends with an R and it's always going to be AR, ER or IR and we had an example of each.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we noticed that for AR, ER and IR verbs, unless the verb is irregular, we will take off that ending and put on an O to get the I version to say I tolerate, for example.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say I tolerate?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you move the accent back as well, which is essential for the present tense.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you said tolero, it would mean he tolerated, which as I mentioned would be useful for us later when we learn this tense.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But it's important in the present tense to have the accent on the penultimate syllable, tolero.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So you don't add on though, you take off the ending.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This also means how or like.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: By coincidence, you might have heard como estas?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for all verbs, we take off the ending and we add O and we get the I version.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But for the rest of the versions, for he, she, it, you, for me, for we, etc.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The verbs split into two groups.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Although we have three different endings, we have two groups.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now most verbs in Spanish are AR verbs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is the biggest group, the group of AR verbs, the verbs that end AR.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In fact, any new verb that comes into Spanish will become, will be crowned as an AR verb.

speaker: Speaker 1

speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for AR, AR, IR, if the verb is regular, we take off the ending, AR, AR, IR, and we put O and we get the I version.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now for the others, the other versions, there's a slight difference between AR verbs and IR verbs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now AR verbs have the vowel A as a principal sound.

text: That's a sound that keeps popping up.

text: When we have one of these little words, te, me, lo, los, la, las, they will come before the changed verb.
